annotations: All-solid-state batteries (ASSBs) have high safety and high energy density. Li10SnP2S12 sulfide solid elec- trolyte has attracted extensive attention due to its low fabrication cost and outstanding performance in ASSBs. However, its ionic conductivity and stability to lithium and air need to be further improved. Here, in order to avoid the formation of impurities related to Sn-related compounds, the content of SnS2 in the raw materials is reduced, and to improve ionic conductivity and stability

to lithium and air. The S site is doped with O by the solid-phase sintering method, and a series of Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9−xOx (0 ≤x ≤ 1) electrolytes are prepared. Li10Sn0.95P2S11.4O0.5 (LS0.95PSO0.5) has a high ionic conductivity of 3.96 mS cm−1 and low activation energy after cold pressing. According to the Hard-Soft-Acid-Base theory, doping O into the electrolyte in advance will improve the stability. The ionic conductivity decay of LS0.95PSO0.5 after exposure to air is smaller, which proves

that O doping improves the air stability of the electrolyte. LS0.95PSO0.5 also shows good stability to lithium. The assembled LNO@LCO/LS0.95PSO0.5/Li-In ASSB exhibits a high first-cycle dis- charge capacity of 133 mA h g−1 and good cycling stability.
Among sulfide solid-state electrolytes, Li10SnP2S12 (LSPS) elec- trolytes prepared from less expensive Sn sulfides have received

extensive attention, which have similar chemical and electro- chemical properties to Li10GeP2S12 (LGPS) [7]. However, the air and electrochemical stability of LSPS still needs to be improved. Nu- merous studies have shown that oxides have good stability and reasonable ionic conductivity [8]. The introduction of O into sulfides helps to improve the performance of electrolytes [9,10]. Considering that the chemical bond between Sn and O is stronger than that between Sn and S, oxygen substitution

is expected to improve thermodynamic stability. For example, after the S in LGPS is partially replaced by O, the ion-conducting properties can still be maintained and the electrochemical stability is improved [11]. In the Li9.54Si1.74 P1.44S11.7−zCl0.3Oz (0 ≤z ≤ 0.6) [10] and Li10SiP2S12−xOx (0 ≤x ≤ 1.75) [12] electrolyte systems, the introduction of O makes the structure more homogeneous and stable, and improves the phase purity. Ac- cording to the Hard-Soft-Acid-Base theory, P will

preferentially combine with O in water vapor in the air, thereby breaking the P-S bond in LSPS, resulting in the decomposition of LSPS. Doping O into the electrolyte can improve the stability of the electrolyte material structure. Electrolytes such as Li6.988P2.994Nb0.2S10.934O0.6 [13] and Li3.06P0.98Zn0.02S3.98O0.02 [14] confirmed that the introduction of O into sulfide electrolytes can achieve better air stability.

All rights reserved.D. Liu, Q. Wang, X. Ma et al.

the content of SnS2 in the raw material and synthesized a series electrolyte. Through XRD and Raman spectroscopy, we study the crystal structure of the electrolyte in which O replaces S in Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9−xOx (0 ≤x ≤ 1). We found that O doping can si- multaneously improve the lithium-ion conductivity and stability to lithium and air.2. Experimental section2.1. Synthesis of Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9−xOx (0 ≤ x ≤ 1) materials

LiCoO2 (99 %), P2S5 (99 %), P2O5 (98 %), SnS2 (99.5 %), and Li2S (99.5 %) were all purchased from Macklin Reagent Company. Li2S, P2S5, SnS2, and P2O5 were weighed in the molar ratio of 5: (1–0.2x): 0.95: 0.2x (0 ≤ x ≤ 1, the total mass was about 1 g), ground and mixed manually in an agate mortar, and sealed in a 100 mL of zirconia ball mill tank (the mass ratio of ball and material was 20: 1). After ball milling at 500 rpm for 4 h, the mixed powder was protected by argon gas and sealed in a

Then two pieces of Li metal were placed on both sides of the pressed electrolyte sheet and pressed with a pressure of 100 MPa. The Li dissolution/deposition experiment was carried out in LANHE battery test system (CT2001A, Wuhan LAND Electronic Co. Ltd., China). The current density was 0.1 mA cm−2 and the test temperature was room temperature.

Assemble and test all-solid-state batteries. The cathode active material was LiNbO3 coated LiCoO2 (LCO@LNO) [17]. The composite cathode material was prepared by grinding in an agate mortar for 30 min with the mass ratio of LCO@LNO: electrolyte powder: con- ductive carbon black= 65: 30: 5. Subsequently, 120 mg of the elec- trolyte powder was taken and pressed into a 12 mm of pellet at a pressure of 100 MPa. Take 10 mg of composite cathode powder and spread it evenly on one side of the

For the Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9−xOx (0 ≤x ≤ 1) electrolytes synthesized by ordinary ball milling and solid-phase sintering methods, their phase compositions were firstly analyzed by XRD, and the results are shown in Fig. 1(a). It can be seen from the figure that in the range of 0 ≤x ≤ 1, there are no other compounds except the main phase LSPS (PDF #01–083–6396). After zooming in on the XRD data near the strongest peak (28–30°), it can be found that with the increase of O doping, the main peak shifted

to higher angles. The shift of the XRD peak position indicates that O was successfully incorporated into the lattice. In addition, in the Li10GeP2S12−xOx series of electrolytes [11], there is a similar phenomenon. Since the radius of S2- is larger than that of O2-, when O enters the lattice, it causes the shrinkage of the unit cell, which shifts the peak to a higher angle.

To verify this conclusion, XRD refinement was performed on Li10Sn0.95P2S11.4O0.5 (LS0.95PSO0.5). LS0.95PSO0.5 belongs to the P42/ nmc space group, and the initial parameters were taken from the structural model reported by LSPS [7]. The fitting graph and re- finement result parameters are shown in Fig. 1(c) and Tab. S1, re- spectively. From the XRD refinement results, good fitting results and lower Rwp values were obtained. The lattice parameters of Å, LS0.95PSO0.5 V= 976.45037 Å3. Compared

with the LSPS synthesized by our pre- vious work [15], the lattice constant decreases and the unit cell volume shrinks. These results clearly show that S is partially re- placed by O. In order to explore the effect of O doping on the local structure of LSPS, the Raman spectra of all samples are shown in Fig. 1(b). In the range of 250–550 cm−1, the peak at 346 cm−1 is the vibrational peak of SnS4 tetrahedron, and the peak at 422 cm−1 is the vibrational peak of PS4 tetrahedron, and no peak

related to O is observed. O doping has no great effect on the main structure. Ac- cording to the XRD refinement results, the crystal structure of LS0.95PSO0.5 is shown in Fig. 1(d). According to the reported refine- ment results of LGPS family electrolytes [10,11], the introduced O is more inclined to bond with P, so O is more inclined to enter the S1 (8 g) site. At the same time, the incorporation of O at this site with P1 (2b) forms a P-S bond, and the O occupancy is close to the theoretical

Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9−xOx (0 ≤x ≤ 1) electrolytes. Fig. 3(a) is the Nyquist diagram of the materials in the high-frequency region. The blocking electrode used in the test is stainless steel. As can be seen from the figure, when the doping amount x = 1, the impedance value is greater than that of Li10Sn0.95P2S11.9 (LS0.95PS), and the impedance values of other doping amounts are smaller than that of LS0.95PS. Fig. 3(b) shows the ionic conductivity of all samples. Corresponding to the impedance

spectra, LS0.95PSO0.5 has the lowest impedance value and the highest ionic conductivity of 3.96 mS cm−1. The sample with x = 1 shows lowest ionic conductivity, so electrolytes with higher O sub- stitution are not further investigated.

the AC impedance values of LS0.95PS and LS0.95PSO0.5 at different temperatures were tested. The Nyquist plots in the high-frequency region are shown in Fig. 3(c) and (d). The blocking electrode used in the test is stainless steel. Through the Arrhenius formula, the activation energy (Ea) of LS0.95PS and LS0.95PSO0.5 was obtained by fitting. The results are shown in Fig. 3(e). The Nyquist plots of the LSPS are shown in Fig. S3. Ac- cording to the fitting results, the Ea values of LS0.95PS and

LS0.95PSO0.5 are lower than that of LSPS, and the Ea values of them are 0.28 and 0.25 eV, respectively. The introduction of O obviously reduces the Ea, which is beneficial to the transport of Li+ [18]. Similar findings were also found in the study on Li10SiP2S12−xOx series electrolytes with the same crystal structure as LGPS [12], that is, after proper O incorporation into Li10SiP2S12, the activation energy decreases, and the ionic conductivity increases.

CV tested the electrochemical window of LS0.95PSO0.5 at room temperature with a scan rate of 1 mV s-1 in the voltage range of − 0.5–5 V (vs Li/Li+). As shown in Fig. 3(f), there is no special fluc- tuation in the CV curves of the three cycles, which indicates that the electrochemical window of LS0.95PSO0.5 is above 5 V. Compared with LSPS [15,19], the CV curves of LS0.95PSO0.5 are smoother and have better electrochemical stability.3D. Liu, Q. Wang, X. Ma et al.

The electronic conductivity of LS0.95PSO0.5 was also tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 4. Fig. 4(a) shows the steady-state current curves after one hour at voltages of 0.1–0.5 V, respectively. Fig. 4(b) is a straight line obtained by fitting the steady-state current corresponding to each voltage, and the slope of the straight line is the DC resistance. The calculated electronic conductivity of LS0.95PSO0.5 is 6.8207 × 10−9 S cm−1, which is 6 orders of magnitude lower than the ionic

conductivity calculated by AC impedance. Moreover, the electronic conductivity of LS0.95PSO0.5 is an order of magnitude lower than that of LSPS [15], which indicates that LS0.95PSO0.5 has a better ability to suppress Li dendrites [20,21].

are shown in Fig. S4. It can be seen from the results that the ionic conductivity of LS0.95PSO0.5 before and after exposure to air has less attenuation and higher air stability.cycling up to 120 h. The impedance changes of the symmetrical battery before and after cycling are shown in Fig. S6. The increase of polarization voltage is related to the increase of LS0.95PSO0.5/Li in- terface impedance.3.3. Battery performance

Introducing oxygen into sulfide electrolytes may be a way to combine the high ionic conductivity of sulfides with the high elec- trochemical stability of oxides [25–27]. In order to further compare the interfacial stability of LSPS and LS0.95PSO0.5 electrolytes to Li, the Li-Li symmetric battery cycling tests are shown in Fig. 5. During the whole cycling process, the polarization voltage of the Li/LS0.95PSO0.5/ Li symmetric cell at room temperature is smaller than that of LSPS. The flat and

axisymmetric polarization curves indicate stable and the reversible lithium plating and delithiation behaviors at LS0.95PSO0.5/Li interface. The detailed lithium plating/stripping vol- tage distributions can be seen in the enlarged regions at different cycle time in Fig. 5(b-d). The polarization voltages of the two elec- trolytes are comparable at the beginning of the cycle. As the number of cycles increases, the polarization voltage of LSPS increases more, indicating that the interfacial
reaction between LSPS and Li metal is more complicated. This indicates that LS0.95PSO0.5 has better elec- trochemical stability to lithium than LSPS.

Since the cycling performance of LSPS at a current density of 0.1 mA cm−2 is worse than that of LS0.95PSO0.5, the performance of LSPS symmetric cells at higher current densities was not tested. The cycle test results of the symmetric battery with LS0.95PSO0.5 as the electrolyte at a current density of 0.2 mA cm−2 are shown in Fig. S5. At the larger current density, the polarization voltage is 0.17 V for

To verify the performance of the battery, ASSBs were assembled with LS0.95PS and LS0.95PSO0.5 as the electrolyte, Li-In as the anode material, and LiNbO3-coated LiCoO2 (LCO@LNO) as the cathode material, respectively. Because the LiNbO3 buffer layer can reduce the interfacial resistance on the cathode side and improve the electrochemical performance [17]. The first two cycles of the battery were performed at a current density of 0.05 C (1 C = 140 mA g−1) in order to obtain a more stable

electrolyte/electrode interface. The charge-discharge curves of LS0.95PS and LS0.95PSO0.5 batteries are shown in Fig. 6(a) and (b). In contrast, the LS0.95PSO0.5 battery ex- hibits a larger charge-discharge specific capacity in the first three cycles, with a discharge specific capacity of 133 mA h g−1 in the first cycle. Fig. 6(c) shows the battery cycle results. The LS0.95PSO0.5 battery shows better cycle performance. More specifically, the LS0.95PS battery shows a first cycle Coulombic

efficiency of 63 %, which is significantly lower than that of the LS0.95PSO0.5 battery (76.3 %). The LS0.95PSO0.5 battery consumes less capacity during the first charge-discharge process, indicating a reduced number of side reactions at the electrode/electrolyte interface. Impedance tests before and after cycling were performed on LS0.95PS and LS0.95PSO0.5 batteries, as shown in Fig. S7 and Fig. 6(d). The impedance increases after cycles, which is one of the reasons for the loss of capacity.

5D. Liu, Q. Wang, X. Ma et al.Journal of Alloys and Compounds 926 (2022) 166731Fig. 6. (a) Charge-discharge curves of LS0.95PS and (b) LS0.95PSO0.5; (c) cycle performance diagram of the battery at room temperature; (d) Nyquist plots of LS0.95PSO0.5battery before and after 20 cycles of cycling.4. ConclusionsDeclaration of Competing Interest

In this work, the substitution behavior of O in the synthesized electrolyte structure was characterized by XRD, and Raman spec- troscopy. O was successfully incorporated into the lattice and par- tially replaced the position of S. The LS0.95PSO0.5 electrolyte exhibits a high ionic conductivity of 3.96 mS cm−1 and has an ionic con- duction activation energy of 0.25 eV. Through air exposure experi- ments, it is demonstrated that the doping of O improves air stability. The electrochemical

stability of LS0.95PSO0.5 to Li metal was de- monstrated by CV and Li symmetric cell tests. The all-solid-state battery using LS0.95PSO0.5 electrolyte exhibits a higher discharge capacity of 133 mA h g−1 and good cycling stability. This work en- riches the understanding of the modification of the LGPS-type electrolyte family by O-doping, and also provides an effective means for the modification of solid-state electrolytes.
